SEARCH
Package gw.api.rest

Class DefaultRestDispatchPlugin

java.lang.Object
gw.api.rest.DefaultRestDispatchPlugin
All Implemented Interfaces:
InternalPlugin, IRestDispatchPlugin, Remote
Direct Known Subclasses:
DefaultCloudDispatchPlugin
public class DefaultRestDispatchPlugin extends Object implements IRestDispatchPlugin
This class is the default implementation of the IRestDispatchPlugin. It can be used as the super class for customer implementations.

  • Field Details

    • DO_NOT_LOG_SUCCESS

      public static final String DO_NOT_LOG_SUCCESS
      Name of the Guidewire Swagger extension property that allows reduce logging for the parent REST operation. Usage example: 
        /health/live:
     get:
       ...
       x-gw-extensions:
          doNotLogSuccess: true
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

  • Constructor Details

    • DefaultRestDispatchPlugin

      public DefaultRestDispatchPlugin()

  • Method Details

    • handleReceiveRequest

      public void handleReceiveRequest(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext)
      This method is called upon receipt of each rest request. The operation handler has not been determined (it may be an unsupported path) and the client has not been authenticated nor have permissions been checked. The implementer should recognize that the raw content is potentially an attack. By default, we do nothing (we only log when the request is completed, not when it begins).
      Specified by:
      handleReceiveRequest in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext

    • handlePreExecute

      public void handlePreExecute(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, User user)
      This method is called upon after the operation has been found and the user authenticated. By default, we do nothing.
      Specified by:
      handlePreExecute in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      user - the user executing the operation, if authentication not required this will be null

    • rewriteResponse

      @NotNull public @NotNull Response rewriteResponse(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, @NotNull @NotNull Response response)
      This method is called just prior to serializing the response (before writing the response), if the operation handler was called and returned successful.

      Specified by:
      rewriteResponse in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      response - the response created from by the operation handler returned value
      Returns:
      a valid response, normally this is just the parameter passed in, but it could also create a new response

    • rewriteErrorInfo

      @NotNull public @NotNull ErrorInfo rewriteErrorInfo(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, @NotNull @NotNull ErrorInfo errorInfo)
      This method permits the customer to change what is revealed in the response for an error. Or if the customer wants to create their own error code hierarchy, they can add the parameter errorInfo as a detail to their newly constructed ErrorInfo. This method is called if there is an error (either during setup, operation execution, or serialization of successful response returned from the operation). This method is called before sending the serialized error information as the response. In this implementation we do nothing to the supplied errorInfo.
      Specified by:
      rewriteErrorInfo in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext, this contains information about the request see RequestContext
      errorInfo - the error that has occurred. Note that this should not be changed (it will be passed to the handleRequestProcessed), but a new errorInfo object can be created.
      Returns:
      the new ErrorInfo object or the passed in errorInfo parameter if unchanged

    • handleRequestProcessed

      public void handleRequestProcessed(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, long elapsedMs, Response handlerResponse, ErrorInfo operationError, Response serializedResponse, ErrorInfo serializationError, Throwable writeException)
      This method is called after the request has been processed, whether there were any error or exceptions. The set of parameters to the method will depend upon whether the request succeeded or whether an error or unhandled exception was thrown during processing, serialization, or writing of the response.

      In the default implementation we only log here. Note that this method is called *after* we finish writing out the response (which should close the output stream). This ensure that even if logging adds some amount of server overhead, it should not impact response latency.

      This method will also close the traceability context, if it was created.

      Specified by:
      handleRequestProcessed in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext see RequestContext
      elapsedMs - the milli secs it as taken to execute any other the above methods and the api itself
      handlerResponse - the response from the api handler
      operationError - any errorInfo from finding and executing the operation handler
      serializedResponse - if there was a handlerResponse, this is the serialized content
      serializationError - any errorInfo from the serialization
      writeException - any exception from the write (typically IOException)

    • handleAsyncResponse

      public void handleAsyncResponse(@NotNull @NotNull jakarta.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest servletRequest, int responseCode, boolean failedBeforeProcessing)
      Description copied from interface: IRestDispatchPlugin
      This method is called when the response is sent to a request that contains the 'Prefer: respond-async' header. It's invoked after closing the response to the request. There are four different ways in which an async request can end:
      • The request is accepted for async processing, and a 202 response code is returned
      • The request is rejected if all executor threads are in use and the async queue is full, and a 503 response code is returned
      • The 'Prefer' header has an errant 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference value, and 400 response code is returned
      • The request completes synchronously. This can happen either because no 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference is specified and the request errors out prior to the API handler beginning, or because the 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference was specified and the request completed prior to the specified time. In this case, the responseCode will match whatever the request completed with.

      Note that the normal handleReceiveRequest and handleRequestProcessed methods will still be invoked when the request actually begins processing, unless the request is rejected due to a full queue or a bad 'wait' or 'wait-ms' preference value, so this method does not need to replicate the logic in those methods.

      Specified by:
      handleAsyncResponse in interface IRestDispatchPlugin
      Parameters:
      servletRequest - the incoming HttpServletRequest
      responseCode - the response code that was sent back to the caller.
      failedBeforeProcessing - true if the request failed before going through normal request processing, such that the normal handleReceiveRequest and handleRequestProcessed methods will not be invoked, and false if the request was either accepted for processing or completed synchronously

    • logWriteException

      protected void logWriteException(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, long elapsedMs, Response handlerResponse, ErrorInfo operationError, Response serializedResponse, ErrorInfo serializationError, @NotNull @NotNull Throwable writeException)
      This method is called if there is a write exception, we don't know if the client has actually received any part of the response. Since the response was not written out successfully, we don't call standardLogResponse.
      Parameters:
      requestContext - the requestContext see RequestContext
      elapsedMs - the milli secs it as taken to execute any other the above methods and the api itself
      handlerResponse - the response from the api handler
      operationError - any errorInfo from finding and executing the operation handler
      serializedResponse - if there was a handlerResponse, this is the serialized content
      serializationError - any errorInfo from the serialization
      writeException - any exception from the write (typically IOException)

    • logSerializationError

      protected void logSerializationError(@NotNull @NotNull RequestContext requestContext, long elapsedMs, @NotNull @NotNull Response handlerResponse, Response serializedResponse, @NotNull @NotNull ErrorInfo serializationError)
      This is called if there is a serialization exception, i.e., we couldn't translate the handler returned entity into the wire format.
      Parameters:

      elapsedMs - the milli secs it as taken to execute any other the above methods and the api itself
      handlerResponse - the response from the api handler
      serializedResponse - if there was a handlerResponse, this is the serialized content
      serializationError - any errorInfo from the serialization
